sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; searches for files. It can search by by filename, modification date or other characteristics.
The search tool can be started by selecting GNOME Search Tool from Utilities submenu of the Main Menu, or by running the command gsearchtool on the command line.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para: GNOME Search Tool provides two types of search: Simple and Advanced. Advanced find is reliable and provides many possibilities, but can be slow. Simple is faster but can only search by filename.

sect1.title: Simple mode
sect1.para: In Simple mode, &app; uses a database containing the names of all the files on the system. It is fast, but only allows searches by file names and will not find files added after the last database update.
To find a file using the quick search mode, enter a substring of the file name in the Search For field and click Find.

To restrict search to a subdirectory, use the directory name in combination with the wildcards. For example, to search for all files with extension txt in the directory /home/user, enter /home/user/*.txt in the Locate file field.
Simple mode uses the locate command. More detailed information is available in the locate manual page.

sect2.title: The locate database
sect2.para: On most systems, the locate database used for Simple search is updated daily, usually automatically at night. You also can running the command updatedb to manually update the database. This requires system administrator (root) privileges. More information is available in the updatedb manual page.

sect1.title: Advance search mode
sect1.para:
The Advanced mode provides more search options.
&app; Advanced Search
Screenshot of advanced search window
To start a search, you must give &app; the search criteria and the directory to start in.

By default, the search starts in the current working directory. If &app; was started from the menu, the current working directory is your home directory. You can change the starting directory by entering any valid path in the Start in directory field, or by choosing a directory using the Browse... button.

&app; allows you to specify multiple search criteria. By default, it uses a single criteria: File name is. Additional criteria can be selected by clicking on the menu next to the Add button. Once a new criterion is selected, click Add. Available criteria include:
File name is — search by filename. You can use the wildcards * and ? in the search. UNIX file names are case-sensitive.
Don't search subdirectories — if this option is selected, GNOME Search Tool will not search the files in the subdirectories of the start directory.
Owned by user — search by the name of the user owning the file.
Owned by group — search by the name of the group owning the file.
Last time modified — search for files which were modified during the last N days (to be precise, during the last N*24 hours).
Don't search mounted filesystems — if this option is selected, &app; will only search in the subdirectories which are mounted on the same device (disk) as the starting directory.
File is empty — this criterion matches the empty file. Mostly used by system administrators for system maintenance.
Invalid user or group — matches files whose owner or group is not known to the system. This option can be useful when searching for files belonging to users who have been removed from the system. Mostly used by system administrators for system maintenance.
File name is not — matches all files except those whose file name is given. As before, you can use wildcards. For example, if you specify in this field *~, GNOME Search Tool will exclude from the search all files with names ending with tilde (~).
Matches regular expression — matches all files that contain given regular expression. Since this option involves reading contents of every file, it can slow down the search significantly.

By default, &app; also searches through all subdirectories of the given directory; you can turn this behavior off by enabling the option Don't search subdirectories. For finer control, you can enable the option Don't search mounted filesystems, which will exclude from the search subdirectories which are physically located (mounted) on drives or partitions other than the starting directory.

After you have specified the search criteria and starting directory, click Find. This will take some time (depending on the directory size and system speed), after which you will be presented with a window containing the list of the files matching your criteria. If the search is taking too much time, you can abort it by clicking Cancel button.

In the search results window, you can double-click on any file to open it. It will have the same effect as double-clicking on this file in a File Manager window — that is, the file will be opened using the default action for this file type.

sect1.title: Authors
sect1.para: GNOME Search Tool was written by George Lebl (jirka@5z.com). Please send all comments, suggestions, and bug reports to the GNOME bug tracking database. (Instructions for submitting bug reports can be found on-line.) If you are using GNOME 1.1 or later, you can also use Bug Report Tool (bug-buddy), available in the Utilities submenu of Main Menu, for submitting bug reports.

This manual was written by Alexander Kirillov (kirillov@math.sunysb.edu). Please send all comments and suggestions regarding this manual to the GNOME Documentation Project by sending an email to docs@gnome.org. You can also add your comments online by using the GNOME Documentation Status Table.
